title: Herrington Country Park Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Brian Abbott / Entrance to Herrington Country Park
images.caption: Child cycling near the Entrance to Herrington Country Park. Herrington Country Park was opened in 2003 on the site of a former colliery and opencast mine. What was once an eyesore with a very large slagheap is being transformed (trees take time to grow!) into a large pleasant leisure area.

images.title: Brian Abbott / Pond in Herrington Country Park
images.caption: Pond in the Country Park. The main pond in the country park is designated as a boating lake. The jetty shown in the middle of the picture is where model boats are launched. It's also regularly used for feeding the waterfowl.

images.title: Brian Abbott / Top point in Herrington Country Park
images.caption: Top point in Herrington Country Park. The topmost point in the country park (80m?) is marked by a sculpture meant to symbolise a fortress with defenders. Good views from here.

images.title: Brian Abbott / Penshaw Monument as seen from Herrington Country Park
images.caption: Penshaw Monument as seen from Herrington Country Park. Taken from the highest, and (roughly) middle, point of the Park. The path up to the monument can be seen winding down the hill below it.

images.title: Brian Abbott / Herrington Country Park and New Herrington village
images.caption: The South-Western part of the Country Park is in the foreground. In the distance is New Herrington village (an ex pit-village).

images.title: Brian Abbott / Lady Beatrice Terrace
images.caption: Lady Beatrice Terrace. Formerly managers' houses for Herrington Colliery, these houses now overlook the Country Park.

images.title: Visitor Centre at Herrington Country Park by peter robinson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Visitor Centre and car park view.

images.title: Brian Abbott / Durham County Show in Herrington Country Park
images.caption: Durham County Show in the summer. Nowadays very much a 'townies' show. Funfair, stalls, horse, dog and other domestic animal shows, but virtually no farm exhibits.

description: This super, large park in Sunderland has a number of cycling and walking trails and interesting environmental sculptures. There is also a boating lake, a nature pond and a sculpture trail. The park is ideal for an easy family cycle ride. The Great North Forest Heritage Trail runs through the park so you could continue your cycle/walk along this route. Also of interest is the Penshaw Monument just to the north of the park. This folly is situated on Penshaw Hill and dedicated to John George Lambton, first Earl of Durham. The video below shows the splendid views from this iconic landmark which appears on the badge of Sunderland Football Club. The riverside James Steel Park in Washington can also be visited in this area.
